required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Nerve Stimulator Versus Ultrasound-guided Infraclavicular Block
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Comparison of Nerve Stimulator and Ultrasound-guided Infraclavicular Block for Upper Extremity Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators compared the postoperative analgesia of nerve stimulator-guided and ultrasound-guided infraclavicular block for upper extremity surgery.

detailed_description.textblock:
Ultrasound (US)-guided peripheral nerve block has increased in popularity. It has many advantages such as improved success rate, faster onset time, fewer needle passes, shorter performance time, and reduced procedural pain and vascular puncture. However, there is no information about postoperative analgesia.
Therefore, the investigators tested whether ultrasound-guided peripheral nerve block enhanced the postoperative analgesia for upper extremity surgery compared with nerve stimulator (NS) guidance.

primary_outcome.description: time from completion of local anesthetic injection until the first request for an analgesic

secondary_outcome.description: the time between the block needle insertion and needle withdrawal
either forward or backward movement of needle at least 1 cm or more
presence of paresthesia during the procedure

secondary_outcome.time_frame: until 30min after completion of local anesthetic
secondary_outcome.description: complete block of sensory nerve (radial, ulnar, median, musculocutaneous, and medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve)
presence of motor block in the operated hand
presence of any paresthesia in the operated extremity
Rescue analgesia with 75 mg of IM diclofenac was available on demand.

The acceptance of the anesthetic technique was evaluated using a two-point score: 1, satisfactory (if necessary, I would have the same anesthetic technique); and 2, unsatisfactory (different anesthetic technique).

arm_group.description: NS-guided infraclavicular block is performed using 35 ml of 0.5% ropivacaine.
US-guided infraclavicular block is performed using 35 ml of 0.5% ropivacaine.

intervention.description: Patients received a standard single injection infraclavicular block using the lateral sagittal approach of Klaastad. The infraclavicular brachial plexus is identified using an insulated needle connected to a nerve stimulator. Placement of the needle is considered adequate if motor response of radial nerve in the hand or wrist is still present at 0.2 - 0.5mA. Ropivacaine 0.5% 35ml is used.

Infraclavicular block is performed under ultrasound guidance. Linear probe is placed in a parasagittal positon below the clavicle medial to the coracoid process and adjusted to achieve a cross-sectional image of the axillary artery. Using in-plane technique, an 22-gauge insulated needle is advanced caudally and posteriorly to the axillary artery. Subsequently, 35 ml of 0.5% ropivacaine is incrementally injected.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- American Society of Anesthesiologists physical class I - III patients scheduled to undergo upper extremity surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- coagulopathy, severe pulmonary disease, neuropathy, contralateral diaphragmatic paresis, allergy to study medications

overall_official.affiliation: Dept. of anesthesia and pain medicine, Cheju Halla General Hospital

reference.citation: Choi S, McCartney CJ. Evidence Base for the Use of Ultrasound for Upper Extremity Blocks: 2014 Update. Reg Anesth Pain Med. 2016 Mar-Apr;41(2):242-50. doi: 10.1097/AAP.0000000000000155. Review.

Koscielniak-Nielsen ZJ. Ultrasound-guided peripheral nerve blocks: what are the benefits? Acta Anaesthesiol Scand. 2008 Jul;52(6):727-37. doi: 10.1111/j.1399-6576.2008.01666.x. Epub 2008 May 12. Review.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Department of Anesthesiology and pain medicine
